alpha.reasoning: Adjust based on sample size, more conservative (lower) values for larger samples. If < 500, use 0.1; Else if 500-10000 (<10000 but >500), use 0.05; Else if > 10000, using 0.01.

indep_test.reasoning: Choose based on data type: 'fisherz' for continuous, 'chisq' for discrete, 'gsq' for mixed data types.

uc_rule.reasoning: Use 0 for standard PC, 1 or 2 for more conservative collider orientations in the presence of faithfulness violations.

uc_priority.meaning: Rule for resolving conflicts between unshielded colliders
uc_priority.reasoning: Higher values (2-4) are more conservative. Use 3 or 4 when you want to prioritize stronger colliders in case of conflicts.

alpha.reasoning: Adjust based on sample size, more conservative (lower) values for larger samples. If < 500, use 0.1; Else if 500-10000 (<10000 but >500), use 0.05; Else if > 10000, using 0.01.

independence_test_method.reasoning: Choose based on data type: 'fisherz' for continuous, 'chisq' for discrete, 'gsq' for mixed data types.

depth.meaning: Maximum depth for fast adjacency search
depth.reasoning: Use -1 for unlimited depth. For large graphs, limiting depth (e.g., 5-7) can significantly speed up the algorithm at the cost of some accuracy.

max_path_length.meaning: Maximum length of any discriminating path
max_path_length.reasoning: Limit for large graphs to improve speed. -1 for no limit, but can be computationally expensive for large graphs.

score_func.reasoning: Use 'local_score_BIC' for a good balance of fit and complexity. 'BDeu' for discrete data. CV and marginal scores for more robust model selection, especially with limited data.

maxP.meaning: Allowed maximum number of parents when searching the graph
maxP.reasoning: Limit maxP for large graphs to reduce computational complexity. No limit (null) for small graphs to explore all possibilities.

max_iter.meaning: Maximum number of dual ascent steps during optimization
max_iter.reasoning: Increase for more complex graphs (with many variables).

h_tol.meaning: Exit tolerance for h(W) during optimization
h_tol.reasoning: Lower values enforce stricter acyclicity. Use lower values for more accurate results, higher values for faster convergence.

w_threshold.reasoning: Higher values lead to sparser graphs. Adjust based on expected graph density and to filter out weak connections.

sparse.reasoning: Use true for sparse optimization, which has better identifiability of the true graph.

beta.meaning: L1 regularization coefficient for edge weights
beta.reasoning: Higher values lead to sparser graphs. Adjust based on expected graph density and to filter out weak connections.

alpha.reasoning: Adjust based on sample size, more conservative (lower) values for larger samples. If < 500, use 0.1; Else if 500-10000 (<10000 but >500), use 0.05; Else if > 10000, using 0.01.

indep_test.reasoning: Choose based on data type: 'fisherz' for continuous, it is fast and general; 'kci' is suitable for nonlinear data but slow (need consider time cost); 'chisq' for discrete, 'gsq' for mixed data types.

depth.meaning: Maximum depth for fast adjacency search
depth.reasoning: Use -1 for unlimited depth. For large graphs, limiting depth (e.g., 5-7) can significantly speed up the algorithm at the cost of some accuracy.

stable.meaning: Whether to use the stable version of the algorithm
stable.reasoning: Use true for more stable results, false for potentially faster but less stable results.

uc_rule.reasoning: Use 0 for standard PC, 1 or 2 for more conservative collider orientations in the presence of faithfulness violations.

uc_priority.meaning: Rule for resolving conflicts between unshielded colliders
uc_priority.reasoning: Higher values (2-4) are more conservative. Use 3 or 4 when you want to prioritize stronger colliders in case of conflicts.

mvcdnod.meaning: Whether to use the MVCDNOD algorithm
mvcdnod.reasoning: Set to true to use the MVCDNOD algorithm, which can handle missing values.

correction_name.meaning: Name of the correction method for the independence test
correction_name.reasoning: Use 'MV_Crtn_Fisher_Z' for Fisher's Z test with missing value correction.

measure.reasoning: Use 'pwling' for pairwise likelihood-based measure, or 'kernel' for kernel-based measure.

random_state.meaning: Seed used by the random number generator
random_state.reasoning: Set to null for random behavior, or a fixed integer for reproducible results.

prior_knowledge.meaning: Prior knowledge used for causal discovery
prior_knowledge.reasoning: Can be set to a matrix where 0 means no path, 1 means a directed path, and -1 means no prior knowledge.

apply_prior_knowledge_softly.meaning: Whether to apply prior knowledge softly
apply_prior_knowledge_softly.reasoning: Set to true to apply prior knowledge in a soft manner, false for strict application.

random_state.meaning: Seed used by the random number generator
random_state.reasoning: Set to null for random behavior, or a fixed integer for reproducible results.

max_iter.meaning: Maximum number of iterations for FastICA
max_iter.reasoning: Increase for potentially better results at the cost of longer computation time.
